trans-unit.source: Run any Windows app on any device with Azure RemoteApp
trans-unit.target: Run any Windows app on any device with Azure RemoteApp

trans-unit.source: Learn how to share any Windows app with your users by using Azure RemoteApp.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to share any Windows app with your users by using Azure RemoteApp.

trans-unit.source: Run any Windows app on any device with Azure RemoteApp
trans-unit.target: Run any Windows app on any device with Azure RemoteApp

trans-unit.source: You can run a Windows application anywhere on any device, right now, seriously - just by using Azure RemoteApp.
trans-unit.target: You can run a Windows application anywhere on any device, right now, seriously - just by using Azure RemoteApp.

trans-unit.source: Whether it's Internet Explorer 6, a custom application written 10 years ago, or an Office app, your users no longer have to be tied to a specific operating system (like Windows XP) for those few applications.
trans-unit.target: Whether it's Internet Explorer 6, a custom application written 10 years ago, or an Office app, your users no longer have to be tied to a specific operating system (like Windows XP) for those few applications.

trans-unit.source: With Azure RemoteApp, your users can also use their own Android or Apple devices and get the same experience they got on Windows (or on Windows Phones).
trans-unit.target: With Azure RemoteApp, your users can also use their own Android or Apple devices and get the same experience they got on Windows (or on Windows Phones).

trans-unit.source: This is accomplished by hosting your Windows application in a collection of Windows virtual machines on Azure - your users can access them from anywhere they have an internet connection.
trans-unit.target: This is accomplished by hosting your Windows application in a collection of Windows virtual machines on Azure - your users can access them from anywhere they have an internet connection.

trans-unit.source: Read on for an example of exactly how to do this.
trans-unit.target: Read on for an example of exactly how to do this.

trans-unit.source: In this article, we're going to share Access with all of our users.
trans-unit.target: In this article, we're going to share Access with all of our users.

trans-unit.source: However, you can use ANY app.
trans-unit.target: However, you can use ANY app.

trans-unit.source: As long as you can install your app on a Windows Server 2012 R2 computer, you can share it using the steps below.
trans-unit.target: As long as you can install your app on a Windows Server 2012 R2 computer, you can share it using the steps below.

trans-unit.source: You can review the [app requirements](remoteapp-appreqs) to make sure your app will work.
trans-unit.target: You can review the [app requirements](remoteapp-appreqs) to make sure your app will work.

trans-unit.source: Please note that because Access is a database, and we want that database to be useful, we will be doing a few extra steps to let users access the Access data share.
trans-unit.target: Please note that because Access is a database, and we want that database to be useful, we will be doing a few extra steps to let users access the Access data share.

trans-unit.source: If your app isn't a database, or you don't need your users to be able to access a file share, you can skip those steps in this tutorial
trans-unit.target: If your app isn't a database, or you don't need your users to be able to access a file share, you can skip those steps in this tutorial

trans-unit.source: Create a collection in RemoteApp
trans-unit.target: Create a collection in RemoteApp

trans-unit.source: Start by creating a collection.
trans-unit.target: Start by creating a collection.

trans-unit.source: The collection serves as a container for your apps and users.
trans-unit.target: The collection serves as a container for your apps and users.

trans-unit.source: Each collection is based on an image - you can create your own or use one provided with your subscription.
trans-unit.target: Each collection is based on an image - you can create your own or use one provided with your subscription.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial, we're using the Office 2013 trial image - it contains the app that we want to share.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial, we're using the Office 2013 trial image - it contains the app that we want to share.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure portal, scroll down in the left hand nav tree until you see RemoteApp.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure portal, scroll down in the left hand nav tree until you see RemoteApp.

trans-unit.source: Open that page.
trans-unit.target: Open that page.

trans-unit.source: Click **Create a RemoteApp collection**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create a RemoteApp collection**.

trans-unit.source: Click **Quick create** and enter a name for your collection.
trans-unit.target: Click **Quick create** and enter a name for your collection.

trans-unit.source: Select the region you want to use to create your collection.
trans-unit.target: Select the region you want to use to create your collection.

trans-unit.source: For the best experience, select the region that is closest geographically to the location where your users will access the app.
trans-unit.target: For the best experience, select the region that is closest geographically to the location where your users will access the app.

trans-unit.source: For example, in this tutorial, the users will be located in Redmond, Washington.
trans-unit.target: For example, in this tutorial, the users will be located in Redmond, Washington.

trans-unit.source: The closest Azure region is **West US**.
trans-unit.target: The closest Azure region is **West US**.

trans-unit.source: Select the billing plan you want to use.
trans-unit.target: Select the billing plan you want to use.

trans-unit.source: The basic billing plan puts 16 users on a large Azure VM, while the standard billing plan has 10 users on a large Azure VM.
trans-unit.target: The basic billing plan puts 16 users on a large Azure VM, while the standard billing plan has 10 users on a large Azure VM.

trans-unit.source: As a general example, the basic plan works great for data entry-type workflow.
trans-unit.target: As a general example, the basic plan works great for data entry-type workflow.

trans-unit.source: For a productivity app, like Office, you'd want the standard plan.
trans-unit.target: For a productivity app, like Office, you'd want the standard plan.

trans-unit.source: Finally, select the Office 2013 Professional image.
trans-unit.target: Finally, select the Office 2013 Professional image.

trans-unit.source: This image contains Office 2013 apps.
trans-unit.target: This image contains Office 2013 apps.

trans-unit.source: Just a reminder - this image is only good for trial collections and POCs.
trans-unit.target: Just a reminder - this image is only good for trial collections and POCs.

trans-unit.source: You' can't use this image in a production collection.
trans-unit.target: You' can't use this image in a production collection.

trans-unit.source: Now, click **Create RemoteApp collection**.
trans-unit.target: Now, click **Create RemoteApp collection**.

trans-unit.source: Create a cloud collection in RemoteApp
trans-unit.target: Create a cloud collection in RemoteApp

trans-unit.source: This starts creating your collection, but it can take up to an hour.
trans-unit.target: This starts creating your collection, but it can take up to an hour.

trans-unit.source: Now you're ready to add your users.
trans-unit.target: Now you're ready to add your users.

trans-unit.source: Share the app with users
trans-unit.target: Share the app with users

trans-unit.source: Once your collection has been created successfully, it’s time to publish Access to users and add the users who should have access to it.
trans-unit.target: Once your collection has been created successfully, it’s time to publish Access to users and add the users who should have access to it.

trans-unit.source: If you have navigated away from the Azure RemoteApp node while the collection was being created, start by making your way back to it from the Azure home page.
trans-unit.target: If you have navigated away from the Azure RemoteApp node while the collection was being created, start by making your way back to it from the Azure home page.

trans-unit.source: Click the collection you created earlier to access additional options and configure the collection.
trans-unit.target: Click the collection you created earlier to access additional options and configure the collection.

trans-unit.source: A new RemoteApp cloud collection
trans-unit.target: A new RemoteApp cloud collection

trans-unit.source: On the **Publishing** tab, click **Publish** at the bottom of the screen, and then click **Publish Start menu programs**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Publishing** tab, click **Publish** at the bottom of the screen, and then click **Publish Start menu programs**.

trans-unit.source: ![Publish a RemoteApp program](./media/remoteapp-anyapp/ra-anyapppublish.png)
trans-unit.target: ![Publish a RemoteApp program](./media/remoteapp-anyapp/ra-anyapppublish.png)

trans-unit.source: Select the apps you want to publish from the list.
trans-unit.target: Select the apps you want to publish from the list.

trans-unit.source: For our purpose, we chose Access.
trans-unit.target: For our purpose, we chose Access.

trans-unit.source: Click **Complete**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Complete**.

trans-unit.source: Wait for the apps to finish publishing.
trans-unit.target: Wait for the apps to finish publishing.

trans-unit.source: ![Publishing Access in RemoteApp](./media/remoteapp-anyapp/ra-anyapppublishaccess.png)
trans-unit.target: ![Publishing Access in RemoteApp](./media/remoteapp-anyapp/ra-anyapppublishaccess.png)

trans-unit.source: Once the app has finished publishing, head over to the **User Access** tab to add all the users that need access to your apps.
trans-unit.target: Once the app has finished publishing, head over to the **User Access** tab to add all the users that need access to your apps.

trans-unit.source: Enter user names (email address) for your users and then click **Save**.
trans-unit.target: Enter user names (email address) for your users and then click **Save**.

trans-unit.source: Add users to RemoteApp
trans-unit.target: Add users to RemoteApp

trans-unit.source: Now, it’s time to tell your users about these new apps and how to access them.
trans-unit.target: Now, it’s time to tell your users about these new apps and how to access them.

trans-unit.source: To do this, send your users an email pointing them to the Remote Desktop client download URL.
trans-unit.target: To do this, send your users an email pointing them to the Remote Desktop client download URL.

trans-unit.source: The client download URL for RemoteApp
trans-unit.target: The client download URL for RemoteApp

trans-unit.source: Configure access to Access
trans-unit.target: Configure access to Access

trans-unit.source: Some apps need extra configuration after you deploy them through RemoteApp.
trans-unit.target: Some apps need extra configuration after you deploy them through RemoteApp.

trans-unit.source: In particular, for Access, we're going to create a file share on Azure that any user can access.
trans-unit.target: In particular, for Access, we're going to create a file share on Azure that any user can access.

trans-unit.source: (If you don't want to do that, you can create a [hybrid collection](remoteapp-create-hybrid-deployment.md) [instead of our cloud collection] that lets your users access files and information on your local network.) Then, we'll need to tell our users to map a local drive on their computer to the Azure file system.
trans-unit.target: (If you don't want to do that, you can create a [hybrid collection](remoteapp-create-hybrid-deployment.md) [instead of our cloud collection] that lets your users access files and information on your local network.) Then, we'll need to tell our users to map a local drive on their computer to the Azure file system.

trans-unit.source: The first part you as the admin do.
trans-unit.target: The first part you as the admin do.

trans-unit.source: Then, we have some steps for your users.
trans-unit.target: Then, we have some steps for your users.

trans-unit.source: Start by publishing the command line interface (cmd.exe).
trans-unit.target: Start by publishing the command line interface (cmd.exe).

trans-unit.source: In the **Publishing** tab, select **cmd**, and then click **Publish > Publish program using path**.
trans-unit.target: In the **Publishing** tab, select **cmd**, and then click **Publish > Publish program using path**.

trans-unit.source: Enter the name of the app and the path.
trans-unit.target: Enter the name of the app and the path.

trans-unit.source: For our purpose, use "File Explorer" as the name and "%SYSTEMDRIVE%\windows\explorer.exe" as the path.
trans-unit.target: For our purpose, use "File Explorer" as the name and "%SYSTEMDRIVE%\windows\explorer.exe" as the path.

trans-unit.source: Publish the cmd.exe file.
trans-unit.target: Publish the cmd.exe file.

trans-unit.source: Now you need to create an Azure [storage account](../storage-create-storage-account.md).
trans-unit.target: Now you need to create an Azure [storage account](../storage-create-storage-account.md).

trans-unit.source: We named ours "accessstorage," so pick a name that's meaningful to you.
trans-unit.target: We named ours "accessstorage," so pick a name that's meaningful to you.

trans-unit.source: (To misquote Highlander, there can be only one "accessstorage.")
trans-unit.target: (To misquote Highlander, there can be only one "accessstorage.")

trans-unit.source: ![Our Azure storage account](./media/remoteapp-anyapp/ra-anyappazurestorage.png)
trans-unit.target: ![Our Azure storage account](./media/remoteapp-anyapp/ra-anyappazurestorage.png)

trans-unit.source: Now go back to your dashboard so you can get the path to your storage (endpoint location).
trans-unit.target: Now go back to your dashboard so you can get the path to your storage (endpoint location).

trans-unit.source: You'll use this in a bit, so make sure you copy it somewhere.
trans-unit.target: You'll use this in a bit, so make sure you copy it somewhere.

trans-unit.source: The storage account path
trans-unit.target: The storage account path

trans-unit.source: Next, once the storage account has been created, you need the primary access key.
trans-unit.target: Next, once the storage account has been created, you need the primary access key.

trans-unit.source: Click **Manage access keys**, and then copy the primary access key.
trans-unit.target: Click **Manage access keys**, and then copy the primary access key.

trans-unit.source: Now, set the context of the storage account and create a new file share for Access.
trans-unit.target: Now, set the context of the storage account and create a new file share for Access.

trans-unit.source: Run the following cmdlets in an elevated Windows PowerShell window:
trans-unit.target: Run the following cmdlets in an elevated Windows PowerShell window:

trans-unit.source: So for our share, these are the cmdlets we run:
trans-unit.target: So for our share, these are the cmdlets we run:

trans-unit.source: Now, it's the user's turn.
trans-unit.target: Now, it's the user's turn.

trans-unit.source: First, have your users install a [RemoteApp client](remoteapp-clients.md).
trans-unit.target: First, have your users install a [RemoteApp client](remoteapp-clients.md).

trans-unit.source: Next, the users need to map a drive from their account to that Azure file share you created and add their Access files.
trans-unit.target: Next, the users need to map a drive from their account to that Azure file share you created and add their Access files.

trans-unit.source: This is how they do that:
trans-unit.target: This is how they do that:

trans-unit.source: In the RemoteApp client, access the published apps.
trans-unit.target: In the RemoteApp client, access the published apps.

trans-unit.source: Start the cmd.exe program.
trans-unit.target: Start the cmd.exe program.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to map a drive from your computer to the file share:
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to map a drive from your computer to the file share:

trans-unit.source: If you set the **/persistent** parameter to yes, the mapped drive will persist across sessions.
trans-unit.target: If you set the **/persistent** parameter to yes, the mapped drive will persist across sessions.

trans-unit.source: Now, launch the File Explorer app from RemoteApp.
trans-unit.target: Now, launch the File Explorer app from RemoteApp.

trans-unit.source: Copy any Access files you want to use in the shared app to the file share.
trans-unit.target: Copy any Access files you want to use in the shared app to the file share.

trans-unit.source: Putting Access files in an Azure share
trans-unit.target: Putting Access files in an Azure share

trans-unit.source: Finally, open Access, and then open the database that you just shared.
trans-unit.target: Finally, open Access, and then open the database that you just shared.

trans-unit.source: You should see your data in Access running from the cloud.
trans-unit.target: You should see your data in Access running from the cloud.

trans-unit.source: A real Access database running from the cloud
trans-unit.target: A real Access database running from the cloud

trans-unit.source: Now you can use Access on any of your devices - just make sure you install a RemoteApp client.
trans-unit.target: Now you can use Access on any of your devices - just make sure you install a RemoteApp client.

trans-unit.source:
## Next steps
Now that you've mastered creating a collection, try creating a [collection that uses Office 365](remoteapp-tutorial-o365anywhere.md).
trans-unit.target:
## Next steps
Now that you've mastered creating a collection, try creating a [collection that uses Office 365](remoteapp-tutorial-o365anywhere.md).

trans-unit.source: Or you can create a [hybrid collection ](remoteapp-create-hybrid-deployment.md)that can access your local network.
trans-unit.target: Or you can create a [hybrid collection ](remoteapp-create-hybrid-deployment.md)that can access your local network.
